text: There are many possible causes as to why this bear is emaciated. It could be going blind. It could have a disease. It could have dental issues. It could be very old. It could have swallowed a bone shard that is piercing it's internal organs. It could be unable to find food. Problem is we the viewers can't know for certain. We are being told to believe one specific potential causation of this bears condition without being presented one shred of supporting proof by the narrator. And where is this bears "brother" we are told she has? Why aren't images shown of him? Because, if the narrator is correct and these bears are starving, he would be in the same emaciated condition as her.

climate.nasa.gov
November 5, 2015
Study: Mass gains of Antarctic ice sheet greater than losses

NASA's Earth Science News Team


A new NASA study says that an increase in Antarctic snow accumulation that began 10,000 years ago is currently adding enough ice to the continent to outweigh the increased losses from its thinning glaciers.

The research challenges the conclusions of other studies, including the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change‚Äôs (IPCC) 2013 report, which says that Antarctica is overall losing land ice.

Funny how reality differs from computer models made by an organization with an agenda.
IPCC is UNEP.  UNEP runs OEF.
OEF: Offshore Oil and Gas Environment Forum: Emissions (OEF). A UNEP web site intended as a "medium to locate and disseminate environmental information concerning the sustainable development of the offshore oil and gas industry".

In-country Capacity Needs Assessments;

author: iLOVburgers32

text: ¬†@The Pope¬† It seems like you can't understand what he's trying to say so I'll try to make it clear for you. The polar bear won't become human dependent if it doesn't even know that humans gave him that carcass in the first place. Polar bears do scavenge from time to time and this one will definitely scavenge the carcass since that it's literally starving to death.
author: No, I'm Squidward

text: ¬†@No, I'm Squidward¬† oh I know what he‚Äôs saying and it‚Äôs the equivalent of me saying me backyard raccoons won‚Äôt become dependent on me throwing out food if it never sees me. Doesn‚Äôt matter so long as the animal got food
author: The Pope

text: ¬†@The Pope¬† Nope, you don't just need the bear to not see you, you need to give it the impression that it died of natural causes. The bear wouldn't know the difference since that the carcass could've literally died from a lot of other reasons. Also let me give you a scenario, imagine yourself as a raccoon, as a raccoon, you grew up in a place where humans would just throw out food, so when you see food on the ground or wherever else you can conclude that it was left there by a human using basic reasoning skills since that they're literally everywhere (also raccoons are quite intelligent so they can definitely figure this out). Now imagine yourself as a bear, you grew up in a place where you can die from a variety of different things and bipedal hairless primates don't just drop food around and if you find a dead carcass you wouldn't just assume that bipedal creatures just dropped it there, you'll just think that they died from other causes so you won't become human dependent. Basically what I'm saying is that raccoons and bears are two different creatures with different behaviors due to their environment, making raccoons a not viable comparison to a polar bear.
author: No, I'm Squidward

text: ¬†@The Pope¬† my apologies for making a long comment, that's just how I talk irl when something controversial happens which I guess what influenced the way I talk with people in the internet. Also if you noticed some grammatical errors or some wrong use of words that's because English isn't my first language.
author: No, I'm Squidward

text: ¬†@No, I'm Squidward¬† no all that matters is it got food it would have otherwise not gotten because of people. It does not matter if it associates good with people.
author: The Pope

text: ¬†@The Pope¬† You already said that, the bear will not become human dependent if the bear doesn't even know that humans dropped off that carcass for him, the bear will just think that it died either because of starvation, infection, cold, etc. The bear will not automatically think "Oh, there's a dead carcass on the ground, must've been dropped of by a human" like it couldn't have died by other reasons, the bear will not know the difference because I'm pretty sure it doesn't even care how it died, it'd just be happy to have something to eat. You won't become dependent on something if it was just done once, people would have to constantly expose themselves while giving the bear food for it to become human dependent. Giving the bear something to eat ONCE is not nearly enough to make it depend on humans for food.
author: No, I'm Squidward

text: ¬†@The Pope¬† Feeding 1 bear 1 dead animal won't affect an entire population of polar bears because polar bears go solo, and even if they're not it's not like they can talk and tell other polar bears "Hey guys! A human fed me 1 time, let's all go depend on humans for food!". That would certainly not happen. A scenario where a population of bears would become human dependent is if we constantly feed a large portion of the polar bears making them depend on us for food. But then again, feeding a starving bear once will not make an entire population of bears human dependent, the chances of this happening is highly unlikely and is quite far fetch if you ask me.
author: No, I'm Squidward

text: ¬†@No, I'm Squidward¬† once again it doesn‚Äôt matter if it associates food with people. It does not matter if it sees or smells a person. It got food. Was it placed there by people? If it was then you‚Äôre giving it food. But That‚Äôs not even the issue. If it gets enough food, which was purposely place there by people, it will become dependent on the food. It will make babies, those babies only exist because you fed wild animals. Those babies will also be dependent on surplus of food provided by people. Without that food they die. This is why you‚Äôre not supposed to feed wild animals. It doesn‚Äôt matter if it‚Äôs just once, you‚Äôre setting an example by doing so. Why not feed all the starving polar bears? Surely that won‚Äôt do any harm.
author: The Pope

text: ¬†@The Pope¬† Feeding the bear once  is just simply not enough for it to become human dependent. Polar bears are opportunistic predators and they'll scavenge and will steal another predators food. If a polar bear steals food that was killed by wolves, would that make the polar bear wolf dependent? No it won't, and it's the same with humans, it would see it as just stealing another creatures food.
author: No, I'm Squidward

text: ¬†@No, I'm Squidward¬† . It doesn‚Äôt matter if it‚Äôs just once, you‚Äôre setting an example by doing so. Why not feed all the starving polar bears? Surely that won‚Äôt do any harm.
author: The Pope

text: ¬†@The Pope¬† It does matter man, get it through your head, doing something once will not automatically cause a chain effect, it's much more complicated than that and especially if the bear doesn't associate the carcass to be caused by humans. I'm not saying that we should feed all starving polar bears either, I'm just trying to make you realize that feeding 1 bear 1 meal won't be enough to make it depend on humans and especially an entire population of it.
author: No, I'm Squidward

text:
‚Äã¬†@No, I'm Squidward¬† "doing something once will not automatically cause a chain effect"
it sets a precedence. It does not matter if you just feed 1 bear 1 meal. It's still wrong to feed wild animals, and doing so only encourages it.
author: The Pope

text: ¬†@The Pope¬† Sure, our scent could be on the carcass and the polar bear can possibly conclude that it was caused by a human but it won't become human dependent. If a wolf injures a prey, but the prey escapes but ended up dying because of its injury and a polar bear finds its dead carcass and smells it and found out that it has the scent of wolf on it would become wolf dependent? Like I said, it won't, and it's the same thing if it was killed by humans.
author: No, I'm Squidward

text: ¬†@The Pope¬† that comment below you rn is part of the comment above you btw.
author: No, I'm Squidward

text: ¬†@The Pope¬† Sure, let's say we encouraged the bear to seek humans for food, but obviously people won't just feed the bear and is more likely to run away from it, the bear will soon realize that this tactic isn't working which will force it to go back to hunting.
author: No, I'm Squidward

text: ¬†@No, I'm Squidward¬† I've said time and time again the polar bear associating the food with people doesn't matter. Wolfs are part of the ecosystem. People, largely, are not. That is a false equivalence to make that comparison.
author: The Pope

text: ¬†@The Pope¬† Sure, like the bear will know that or even know what an ecosystem is.
author: No, I'm Squidward

text: ¬†@No, I'm Squidward¬† It doesn't matter what the bear knows.
author: The Pope

text: ¬†@Gaius ¬† I mean, in general yes, but this is a pretty extreme case that I think might justify feeding it, especially if done correctly. The bear really just needed enough to carry them through another month. Hell, why not lay a fresh seal carcass where you know the bear is about to go so that it finds it without interacting with humans?

text:
Early in life, I began wondering that since very little of a tree is left behind as solid residue when it‚Äôs burned, how is it that the bulk of a tree‚Äôs mass is vaporized?¬†
Behind the answer lies another question ‚Äî
‚Ä™https://www.canr.msu.edu/news/where_do_trees_get_their_mass_from‚Ä¨

To begin with, half of the mass of wood is carbon that, when burned, combines with atmospheric oxygen and is released as carbon dioxide (CO2): a unit of carbon combines with two of oxygen. Since the mass of oxygen weighs more than three times as much as carbon, burning just two pounds of wood yields over eight pounds of CO2.
[1 pound carbon + 3.6 pounds oxygen + 3.6 pounds oxygen = 8.2 pounds of carbon dioxide]

Note: Trees, as they grow, re-absorb carbon dioxide from the air; but, with increasing deforestation, desertification, soil degradation, et al, CO2 levels in the biosphere are increasing (especially when you factor in the burning of stupendous amounts of previously sequestered carbon in the form of fossil fuels).

This strengthens the greenhouse effect and results in a steadily warming planet. And with each and every year being warmer than the years before, how is it that only the blissfully ignorant and the hopelessly naive fail to see what the future holds?

author: mcmuffins

text:
Weird. How do I interpret the information I will share below, and what do I do with it? What is the actual truth when everything contradicts everything else?
The video you all just saw was made in September, when the polar ice is at it's minimum. The documentary admittedly picked this one bear in bad shape and didn't show others in close proximity. It was debunked on numerous occasions, even unintentionally by National Geographics documentary made later that year. 

[edit] 
Scott Sound
9 hours ago
It was Sick not starving ............ 

Exactly.
[/edit]

After the announcement that in March 2017 the ice shrunk to it's record low since 1979, NASA gave the next statement in December: polar ice back to 1979 levels, record high thickness recorded. Articles published in October of 2017 claiming the same were declared false. Same happened in 2014, and Here's what Forbes writes later on the subject: "Updated data from NASA satellite instruments reveal the Earth‚Äôs polar ice caps have not receded at all since the satellite instruments began measuring the ice caps in 1979. Since the end of 2012, moreover, total polar ice extent has largely remained above the post-1979 average." The article was now removed due to: failing to meet the editorial standards". One of the latest NASA statement says the thickest ice is at second latest recorded minimum while another, a few months apart shows the thickest ice is growing in thickness since 2014 and is record high for the past decade. Another thing, National Geographics, Feb. 1st 2018. "Polar Bears Really Are Starving Because of Global Warming, Study Shows", where the previous NG estimated population of polar bears was 21000, all other estimates were 26000, while estimates given by biologists were 31000 in 2015 (PBaC, PBSG, PBI and IUCN) with the margin of error that puts the minimum above 28000. In the winter of 2018/2019 the record high of polar bear population was recorded, and even Inuit chiefs asked the Canadian government to intervene due to polar bear attacks increasing by over 300%, and to quote one of Inuit leaders: They are EVERYWHERE. Meanwhile PBI deleted the original 2015 data and replaced it with 23000 in 2018, and conveniently, their funding got raised after that. PBI also now calls the polar bear population rising a myth (Dr. Steven C. Amstrump, USGS polar bears project leader). Extrapolated data from all mentioned suggests the polar bear population in 2019 was, on average 39000. For comparison, the largest estimate in the 60s was in 1964-1966 at 10000, while others ranged from 5000 to 8000. "Official" statistics still claim the polar bear population decrease ranging from 30% to 60%. Canadian Geographics research shows the population increase of 233% since the 70s. University of Alberta gives an estimate as high as 40000 with minimum of 36000, while some credible estimates go as high as 52000 and some not credible as high as 60000. If we would observe all 19 subpopulations of polar bears, only one has a decrease in the past few years, while having an increase for the past 50 years, 4-7 are steady, depending on study, and the data for the rest (usually 9 but goes as high as 12) are replaced with: outaded or unreliable, and not giving exact numbers anymore, since 2017, and since August 2019, the data from as far back as 2012 was also replaced as outdated or unreliable (one can easily compare the currently available articles and statistics with archived ones).
WT actual F?!

author: Garrison Gentry

text:
¬†@Garrison Gentry¬† How would that help? Look, the issue isn't total quantity of seals. It's the fact that the ice has melted so that the bears can't access them until later and later into the year. So this is not a zero sum game where helping one bear means another will be impoverished, nor are there near enough of them for that to plausibly even really be a factor. 

Personally, I think it's perfecly reasonable to have a 'polar bear life support' program that helps the ones closest to deaths door through the months lost due to global warming so that they can survive another year and potentially reproduce. And I think it could be done in a responsible way that limits direct interaction with people while also not encouraging reliance on human food sources.

text:
Typical fear mongering. Does anyone think that no bears go through phases of natural starvation due to age or lack of food source? Well over 99.9% of all living species on this planet have gone extinct over the millennium, it's part of evolution. A favourite one is some narrator gloomily predicting the imminent demise of these species whilst showing one swimming miles from land. They've excellent swimmers and have adapted to swim 100s of miles between islands and ice formations so nothing unusual there are all. 
There have been much warmer climates in the past than we have now, whilst weather patterns do change hotter and cooler over time, there is a growing community that just don't believe the recent spate is a result of burning fossil fuels.

text:
Polar Bear Meme


I suspect that Al Gore undertook considerable focus group research to determine the remarkable effectiveness of the notion that climate change would endanger polar bears. His use of an obviously Photoshopped picture of apathetic polar bear on an ice float suggests this. As Susan Crockford, aspecialist in polar bear evolution, points out, there had indeed been a significant decrease in polar bear population in the past due to hunting and before that due to commercial exploitation of polar bear fur. This led to successful protective measures and sufficient recovery of polar bear population, so that hunting is again permitted.13 There is no evidence that changes in summer sea ice have had any adverse impact on polar bear population, and, given that polar bears can swim for over a hundred miles there seems to be little reason to suppose that it would. Nonetheless, for the small community of polar bear experts, the climate-related concerns have presented an obvious attraction.

¬†@Katie¬† "increasing climate change/ global warming traumatically.
It‚Äôs a natural thing that would happen whether humans existed or not but we are making it happen at a fast rate." ..............Actually, there is no evidence for that. The IPCC states that its models have been wrong. They say that the climate is too complex a system for any long term prediction to be possible. In fact, they say that they are not making predictions, but rather they are laying out scenarios in order to study the processes involved in climate change (which is the functions of models in science). Their mandate is to study HUMAN caused change, so other elements involved in change they say they are not studying. They also say that the extent of change seen cannot be separated out statistically from normal variation. It is the IPCC itself that says this.

author: xuanzhe1

text:
This is nature. The whole story isn't told here. This "story" is for nothing more than pushing a narrative...and you all eat it up.
Do you look at a frail old person and blame "global warming"???
Polar bears, being the top predator in their environment will most likely die of old age. Their bodies slow down, can't catch food...and ultimately starve to death, if they're not finished off and cannibalized by another. This sort of thing has gone on for millions upon millions of years, for millions of species. It's nothing new. Millions of species have gone extinct, long before we were even here. 
The fact is...polar bears are actually doing quite well, and their numbers are actually increasing. Each individual bear will eventually suffer and die...just like the individual in this video.
That is nature.
author: Fermiticus

text:
xuanzhe12.... why illegal?

1. By feeding, you create a "dependant". They will take the easy meal (naturally, just like any creature) and lose the ability to hunt and feed themselves effectively.
Just like most of us have become very dependant on restaurants and grocery stores for our food. Can you go out into the wild and feed yourself?
2. They will look to humans for food...when a human doesn't have food to give...we humans are a very easy and soft target for them.
This becomes very dangerous, and the animals that lose their fear of humans will likely be shot, to protect ourselves. Or, they have to be tranquilized and moved a great distance, at great expense. Best to just leave them be and let nature take its course.

text:
Lady OreoXD, this was a sick bear. National Geographic apologized for using a photo of the bear as a sign of climate change. The truth is that polar bear populations aware on the rise. They keep telling you that the sea ice is disappearing, which it is but not by that much. Since 1979, when they began keeping an ongoing record of ice minimum and maximum, the Arctic maximum has shrunken by 9.8%. Since 1972, when they started restricting polar bear hunting, the population has grown from around 7,000 bears to over 30,000. 
Here is the apology from National Geographic.
https://nationalgeographic.com/magazine/2018/...

Study: Mass gains of Antarctic ice sheet greater than losses

NASA's Earth Science News Team


A new NASA study says that an increase in Antarctic snow accumulation that began 10,000 years ago is currently adding enough ice to the continent to outweigh the increased losses from its thinning glaciers.

The research challenges the conclusions of other studies, including the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change‚Äôs (IPCC) 2013 report, which says that Antarctica is overall losing land ice.

text: Okay this is the misconception that the mainstream media has created about global warming.  Global warming is something that is happening, but it is something that is not created by our emissions of fossil fuels, it is just the natural cycle of our planet.  During the Cambrian era, atmospheric CO2 was around 7000 ppm or parts per million, compared to the atmosphere today which has a little over 400 ppm of atmospheric CO2.  Additionally, the average temperature on our planet currently is 14 degrees Celsius, while it has been over 25 degrees celsius before.  The Earth undergoes cycles in temperature, and we are currently heading out of an ice age, so the polar caps are natural going to be melting and temperatures are going to be increasing.  The mainstream media will bring up the receding ice caps many times, misinforming audiences, because for millions of years there have been no ice caps on this planet, and life has still thrived.  Climate change is real, but is not caused by our CO2 emissions.  It is just a natural cycle on the Earth that will affect the environment around us, but since life was first on Earth species have died off and new ones have emerge.  This is just what cruel mother nature does.

text: There are 20 - 25,000 polar bears in the arctic. The global warming movement only cares about animals that fit their narrative. In the late 1800s there were 100,000 tigers. There are now only 3,500 left in the wild. There are only around 4,000 rhinos. There are only about 800 Mountain Gorillas. None have perished because of climate change. For over a hundred years plants and animals have been decimated resulting from habitat loss and poaching. The climate change movement doesn't care. Humans do exponentially more damage than global warming ever will. In 2016 humans slaughtered 100,000,000 sharks. That isn't a typo. I doubt a single shark has died from climate change. If the Polar bear goes extinct, It will be because of human encroachment not climate change. Grizzly bear habitat is actually expanding because of climate change. Humans as usual encroach on grizzly bear habitat pushing them further and further north where they are able to survive because of a warming planet. Don't tell this to the climate change zealots though. Every predator on earth dies of starvation. They get old and can no longer hunt or defend themselves. Skinny polar bears are nothing new.

So although "global warming" is real, the fault of us is not.

text: Isn't that what every polar bear looks like when they're near the end? Everybody dies, and it's never very pretty...

text: Polar bear populations are still growing despite global warming, according to new research. The new population estimates from the 2016 Scientific Working Group are somewhere between 22,633 to 32,257 bears, which is a net increase from the 2015 number of 22,000 to 31,000. The current population numbers are a sharp increase from 2005‚Äôs, which stated only 20,000 to 25,000 bears remained ‚Äî those numbers were a major increase from estimates that only 8,000 to 10,000 bears remained in the late 1960s. Scientists are increasingly realizing that polar bears are much more resilient to changing levels of sea ice than environmentalists previously believed, and numerous healthy populations are thriving. ‚ÄìAndrew Follett, The Daily Caller, 16 February 2017

text:
¬†@Eduardo Gameiro¬† A slight correction sir, 5000-8000 in 50s, 8000-10000 in 1964-1966, 20000-21000 in the 80s.
"a number again confirmed in 2005 per NYT, International Bear Association, and IUCN" - true, even the actual number was 22000-26000.

"Nowadays the last source even estimates the number of these creatures to be between 22 and 31 000." - if we'd observe only PBS, IUCN, IBA etc even IFF, however, Canadian Geographics research, backed up by University of Alberta gives the estimate of up to 40000at average of 36000, and some estimates go even higher. The most reserved estimate gives an increase of polar bear population by 233% since the 70s. To quote one of the Inuit leaders, after the data that polar bear attacks increased by 300% and up to 400% in some areas: They are everywhere. The three lowest reliable numbers I could find, for 2019 are 28500, 29000 and 31000, and the lowest unreliable number I could find was 22000. The three highest reliable numbers I could find were 39000, 40000 and 52000, where the highest unreliable number was 60000.
"I think it's you who needs to do his own research." - there are roughly 15 studies that are easy to find and about 47 I think that I read,  that show that under 25% of people do their own research (studies were performed to determine how many people believe in titles without reading the text), where the most reasonable number is 20-22%, and the worst I found was peaking 17.5% where it relates to any given information, and goes as low as 11%. 

[edit] Over 40% of people believe tweets without verifying the information.

text: Reuse I agree with, but although recycling does save raw material, in terms of greenhouse gasses curbside recycling actually emits more greenhouse gasses than it reduces. because another garbage truck has to come around.  When you pickup your raw materials a few grams at a time from millions of stops with the most fuel inefficient vehicle going you actually add more greenhouse gasses than you save.  The proof is free raw materials + lower energy cost = less expensive product.  But goods made from recycled material cost more even though the resources are free.  So we are getting hosed by the recycling industry or they are using more energy than traditional industry not less.

Agriculture is a big emitter of greenhouse gases.  Both methane and carbon dioxide.   I am not disputing this. But I refuse to believe that carbon dioxide is the main driving force in climate because environmentalist exaggerate everything.  They understate or overstate, or they use upper or lower edges of 95% confidence bands to predict the worst.  They cannot even tell the difference between a fact and an assumption.

Yes, also eating Kiwi fruit also disproportionately emits carbon dioxide, if it is shipped by Air Cargo, from New Zealand to Canada.  New Zealand lamb, seems that some people believe it tastes better than Canadian lamb.  I don't know why they think that, marketing perhaps.  I would think the biggest effect on the taste of lamb is the breeding and the food you feed them.  Yet we import a lot of lamb from New Zealand here in Canada.

text:
ice melts.  less seals, and less places where seals roost.  Less seals, = less food.  most species, will not breed if there's not enough food to support the process (humanity is different in this respect, we just fucking breed without thought).  More adult polar bears die due to malnutrition and less breeding occurs, compounding the issue of population.  

Fish are disappearing because of changes in sea water's acidity - when the simplest food source (plankton) starts to disappear, it has a knock on effect to every species above it in the foo chain.  

It's rather elementary, but it seems many Americans have been brainwashed by their government and news and  businesses into believing that global warming isn't an issue, when it most assuredly is.

text:
I made a point about this comment section being overrun by climate change deniers- which it overwhelmingly is. You cannot question someones intellect based on what you think they might've be talking about. I haven't mentioned polar bear populations at all but let's just say I did; one of the most frequent myths about polar bears is that their numbers are increasing. I'm guessing this is something you've just heard or quickly read over and not studied. Population data dates back to the 60's. 
Scientists today can't rely on that loose data to determine the actual population at that time. It's not accurate and so you can't work with it. The most important point is that whatever happened in the past is really irrelevant. Polar bear habitat is disappearing due to global warming today and that poses huge threats to their future on this planet. I really hope I don't have to explain why habitat loss due to climate change is a threat to the existence of polar bears.
Climates do change, yes. Luckily, that happens naturally over the course of thousands- even hundreds of thousands of years. The rate in which humankind is doing it, is happening so fast, nothing can keep up and as a result of changing our atmospheric chemistry, we are causing the Anthropocene. 
Don't come on to youtube with your bedroom degree and argue with scientists, Jeremy.

There have been hundreds of years long droughts in California in the last thousand years or so. So when you see a skinny polar bear swimming towards an ice chunk, don't act surprised. Polar bears only really date to the glacial periods anyway. Why would anyone expect them to do any better in an interglacial period .
     Look, I'm not denying that we're ruining the planet. I'm not denying that the climate changes. It's people like you who insult moderate viewpoints that cost the environmental movement a lot of support.

author: Womp Bozer

text:
+Surfnsound
Look carefully into the Vostok ice-core samples and you will see that the "causative relationship" between atmospheric CO2 levels and the Earth's temperature takes place in the opposite order to what they imply they do. In other words, instead of the changes in CO2 affecting the temperature, it is the changes in temperature that affect the CO2 levels, and with a time lag of 800 years as the oceanic temperatures gradually rise or lower to match the atmospheric temperature. And then if you press them on it, they start handing you "peer reviewed" papers that explain how a "positive feedback phenomenon" somehow explains the inconsistency of the event orders. The fact is that they are counting on you being too dumb and lazy to go to all the work of getting past their bodyguard of lies - so prove them wrong.  

So, instead of calling me a brain dead flat-earther or something, why don't you get on the integrity wagon and research the Vostok ice-core samples. I'm not filling your head with right-wing propaganda, I'm just emploring you to study the subject with an attitude of critical thinking rather than anti-conservative rage...

text:
Evolution. The North Pole has been frozen for around 2.7 million years. Polar bears, like all species on earth, would've evolved to their environment over a long period of time. Anywhere between 150,000 to 1.7 million years ago. They would've originally, when they first went to the Arctic, still been closely related to brown bears. 

They're losing their habitat at speeds they cannot keep up with. They rely wholeheartedly on sea ice so that they can hunt. Even with sea ice, they're only successful with 30% of their hunts. I don't understand why you would use your time to be a part of the problem and not the solution? It's clear that we are causing their habitats to decrease at a level that is not natural. We are causing a mass extinction all over the globe and you choose to argue pettily that we are not. You come to the table urging people to read up on ice core samples and you think science as a whole should go off that one, arguable piece of information? It's outrageous. Beaufort and Chukchi Seas sector was the lowest ever observed in the sea ice record this year.
author: Joe McKenzie

text:
Joe McKenzie You are assuming that there is a solution. We and the bears both emerged during a series of ice ages. We know from the geological record that the sheet ice has been melting for quite some time. When ice cores were mentioned he wasn't referencing the ice thickness, he was referencing the co2 concentration. 
       I live in an area where the evidence for glaciation is widespread and it's easy to show anyone that this is true. 
      Are you a glacier denier? What makes you think that glaciers will just lay around forever?  A few million years is not that long in the big picture. Have you considered that they were already melting when humans emerged?
     Why is it that the melting is all our fault, but any melting prior to humans is natural?
Homo sapiens may have never evolved at all if it wasn't for the very temporary ice age that you seem to lament. 
       If you see a puddle with frogs in it, do you cry when the puddle dries up? Species evolve to fit their environment. The environment changes through time and so does the population that fills it.

text:
jeremy campbell & Chris Jones This is not a "belief system" as you so strangely call it. I'm an ecologist. I haven't called anyone an idiot. I haven't used that word- and while I'm proving that point I'd just like to say that, if you're going to deny everything I say, then you do need to at least be some sort of scientist to squeeze into the 3% that deny the simple science I am explaining to you.

Things that normally happen in geologic time are happening during the span of a human lifetime. 

Everywhere on earth ice is changing. The snows of Kilimanjaro have melted more than 80 percent since 1912. Glaciers in the Garhwal Himalaya in India are retreating so fast that researchers believe that most central and eastern Himalayan glaciers could virtually disappear by 2035. Arctic sea ice has thinned significantly over the past half century, and its extent has declined by about 10 percent in the past 30 years. NASA's repeated laser altimeter readings show the edges of Greenland's ice sheet shrinking. Spring freshwater ice breakup in the Northern Hemisphere now occurs nine days earlier than it did 150 years ago, and autumn freeze-up ten days later. Thawing permafrost has caused the ground to subside more than 4.6 meters in parts of Alaska. From the Arctic to Peru, from Switzerland to the equatorial glaciers of Man Jaya in Indonesia, massive ice fields, monstrous glaciers, and sea ice are disappearing, fast. 

When temperatures rise and ice melts, more water flows to the seas from glaciers and ice caps, and ocean water warms and expands in volume. This combination of effects has played the major role in raising average global sea level between 10 and 20 centimeters in the past hundred years, according to the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change(IPCC).

Are you going to deny significant sea level rise? Glaciers that have been there for thousands of years suddenly retreating? 

"As soon as you realize that we can have an intelligent conversation." - Jeremy Campbell

There is no having an intelligent conversation with anyone on here, it seems.
author: Surfnsound

text:
And here you go once more, with the false accusations. I have stated clearly that it appears the earth is warming- yet you choose to ignore it and go for the low hanging fruit as usual. Melting ice is what I would expect to see if the earth was warming. It doesn't do you any good to write a whole paragraph about different melting pieces of ice. Would you care if I wrote about places where the ice was getting thicker? I doubt it. But those places exist. You've once again shown that you're reading skills are in question. 
       Please don't try to quote the "97% consensus ". That is a well known sham study with awkwardly framed questions, where the researchers threw out most of the data that didn't support their conclusions. 
      You don't realize that agw is a belief system. It's complete with a moral code and a punishment system for keeping people in line. You are like a fish in water because you can't see it. It's like trying to explain to a Hindu that Shiva isn't real. You won't see past your own beliefs and entertain the notion that temperature, sea level and co2 have always been changing. But you have no problem calling others deniers. I'm not even saying it's not our fault, I'm just saying that you are ignoring pertinent questions and sticking your head in the sand. 
     As for sea level rise, the rate has risen way faster in the past on multiple occasions. What about all the poor people who lost their homes on the Asia land bridge? That's all under water now. It's probably your fault, too. 
       When you accuse me of denying everything you say, it makes it hard to have an intelligent conversation. It's a dishonest strategy that probably feels good to you, like your landing blows. You don't even recognize the points that we agree on because you are so attached to your agw apologetics.
author: Womp Bozer

text:
I understand perfectly what you're saying. You're trying to tell me that this is all natural, and that we are not the driving force behind this. That glaciers have always been melting and we're probably not the cause of this and even if we are it doesn't matter because it's always happened.
 
It's just picking one piece out of a huge issue when you say it like that. 
There is such a thing as natural deglaciation. That is undeniably true.

My argument is that we are accelerating this process today, at levels certainly not seen within human existence.
What is true, is that the atmospheric chemistry today, is massively different to that of our early ancestors and this is entirely our doing. You know what happens when carbon is emitted into the atmosphere, so knowing that it's happening constantly, at ever growing rates leaves very little to the imagination, let alone experiment.

We are heating up our planet so fast, that ice is melting faster than it would naturally, having dire consequences to the natural world as it simply will not be able to adapt. That's all I am saying.

It's just one part of climate change that we're going to suffer from.

text: simon6071 You're not correct at all. First off, about the Earth going through natural cycles of climate change, yes that is totally true. However, the effects of that natural change are extremely slow, and if it was just the natural change occurring we would not see any difference in over 100 years. But in the last 100 years we have seen a gigantic difference. I myself am born and raised in Alaska, and have seen the effects first hand. It no longer stays cold throughout the whole winter. We get random warm spells in the middle of December and all the snow melts. My grandpa has told me how when he was a kid it was below zero nonstop for weeks on end in Anchorage. I've seen it get below zero a handful of times there. As far as scientist being controlled by the government, that is just simply bullshit. The goal of scientists is to prove each other wrong and discover new things, because doing that = money. But all scientists of any kind with any kind of real education agree that climate change is very real. I don't know why people like you choose to ignore the truth. There is an EXACT correlation with the amount of carbon emissions and the rise of global temperatures. Do you ignore it because you think not using fossil fuels will ruin the economy or something? The way an economy works is that as a product becomes less efficient and ethical, a new product replaces it, and the people who worked on making the first product transition into jobs making the new one. This has happened over and over throughout history. It's people like you who do nothing but divide this country & the world by spouting ignorance. I'm not a "leftard" either, I'm an actually sane person in the middle who realizes that the far left and right are both mentally defective.

text:
Let me guess, you watched Steve Crowder's video on "DEBUNKED: Top 5 "Climate Change" Myths" and thought this video is false because Crowder claims that number of polar bears in the world has increased.

In Crowder's video, his source (factcheck.org) says that the number of polar bears has indeed increased due to the legislation of banning polar bear hunting since 1970. However, there is one thing he forgot to mention (or deliberately didn't mention) in his source that many scientist also believes this trend is reversing because of the climate change and other environmental factors.

Now, even Crowder's own source claims there is a possibility that the number of polar bears are decreasing because of the climate change but for some reason he didn't bother to mention about it in his video. Why do you think he didn't do it? I think you are already know the answer.
